Title: the holographic excitation

Scene: Howard and Bernadette’s bedroom. Howard and Bernadette are dressed as smurfs.
Howard: Oh, hey, Stuart, I got you a little souvenir from my trip to space.
It’s my official NASA portrait.
That’s not true. At the Walgreens I was over the moon for their store-brand antacids.
But you know what wasn’t a party? That hotel in Kazakhstan they put you up in before the launch. I mean, it’s your last night on Earth. You’d think you’d get one porn channel.
Anywhere but the Space Station. On a good day, dinner was a bag full of meat loaf. But, hey, you don’t go there for the food, you go there for the view.
Not really.
You know, people say the Soyuz capsule was a lemon. But, hey, that baby got me to space and back.
Creature from the Black Forest Ham Lagoon.
That reminds me, I was thinking about wearing my NASA jumpsuit as a costume. But then I realized everyone would be, like, where’s your costume? Why are you wearing your work clothes, you nut?
You know where’s there’s a lot of nothing.
Boy, it’s nice to sleep in a bed with gravity again. Did I tell you about the night my retainer floated out of my mouth and into the air lock?

So, here we are, just a couple of young newlyweds. What to do? What to do to you? Astronaut Wolowitz, reporting for booty. Preparing thrusters. We have liftoff. Are we clear to jettison that nightgown?
What?
I don’t talk about it every minute.
What was I supposed to talk about? We were eating at Johnny Rockets.
So, I did this amazing thing and I’m never allowed to mention it?
Okay, no problem. It won’t happen again.
I love you, too. I can’t tell you how many times I dreamed I was in bed here with you when I was… you know. What, I can’t even point?
I don’t care. Get the Tardis.
Yeah, sure, whatever.
Clever.
Nothing.
Okay, here it is. Bernadette said you guys are all sick of me talking about my trip to space. Is that true?
You know what, guys? Never mind. I just won’t talk about the greatest achievement of my life ever again.
Fine.
To tell you the truth, I’m not really in the mood.
Yeah, some friends. They all think I’m boring. Maybe you should go without me.
I’m sorry. I just don’t want to go.
Fine. Two weeks ago I was an astronaut.
Who cares?
You’re right, the party’s fantastic. Please, tell me more. I haven’t heard enough about it all week because hearing about that never gets old.
Well, I’m not allowed to talk about it, but since you brought it up, I went to space! Space, space! Space! Space, space! Space!
Great, now I’m in trouble. You happy?
No, I’m not. They’re all being rude. And you’re being rude.
You’re my wife. You’re supposed to be on my side.
Then why are you trying to take this away from me? Being an astronaut is the coolest thing I’m ever gonna do. If I stop talking about it, then I’m just…
Just plain old Howard Wolowitz again.
You’re just saying that.
I love you.
I don’t know. Raj sent me some video of Buzz Aldrin.
Okay, I get it.
Stuart: Well, Howard, that’s very nice of you.
To Stuart, your comic book store is out of this world. Just like the guy in this picture was.”
Yeah, it’s my annual attempt to meet women. Ninth time’s the charm.
Thanks, but I can’t afford je ne sais quois. How much for just quois?
Oh, yes, thank you. I like to think of fun things like that because I’m fun. I’m not clinically depressed at all.
Hey, hey, look at you guys!
Leonard: Yeah, maybe. Open it first.
Have you noticed that Howard can take any topic and use it to remind you that he went to space?
Okay. Hey, Howard, any thoughts on where we should get dinner?
Hey, what are you doing here?
Oh, what a nice surprise. I don’t think you’ve ever seen my lab before.
No. Although Howard was making some real strides in that area until he met Bernadette.
Nope. Now the Lisatronic 3000 just sits in a box waiting for the phone to ring.
Oh, no, no, no, don’t look in there.
No, it’s a nitrogen laser. It’ll cook your eyeball like a soft-boiled egg.
Sign right there.
Uh, that is an integrated ion trap and time-of-flight mass spectrometer.
That is a pencil sharpener.
It’s actually pretty neat.
Yeah. It’s a front-projected holographic display combined with laser-based finger tracking. Here, I’ll show you. We’ll just put this pencil over here.
Very good. And then a laser will map the reflective surface, and voila. (A floating 3D image of the pencil appears. Leonard moves it around with his finger)
You know, there’s a foundational idea in string theory that the whole universe may be a hologram.

Uh-huh. Well, the holographic principle suggests that what we all experience every day in three dimensions may really (changes view to solar system) just be information (changes view to the galaxy) on a surface located at the farthest reaches of our cosmos. (Starts the galaxy spinning) So it’s possible that our lives are really just acting out a painting on the largest canvas in the universe.
What?
You should visit more often. What are you doing?
What? Here? Now?
No, no. It’s kind of crazy. I’ve never fooled around in the lab before.
No. I did have a shot with the Lisatronic, but the extension cord wasn’t long enough.
Hello, boys.
Nothing.
So, basically, this is what’s called mag-lev technology. It uses very powerful electromagnets to create a force strong enough to overcome gravity. Here, you hold this.
Yeah. Oh, uh, you don’t have on any jewellery, do you?
A grad student forgot to take out one of his piercings. Now he’s on a transplant list waiting for a nipple his size. Now watch this.
Sometimes I like to turn this on and pretend I’m the super villain Magneto.
But what I really am is a very smart scientist who understands the mechanics of the universe and is wearing the sexy black underwear you bought him.
Hello, boys.
Ja, und later she’s going to arrest me for goink fashter zen da shpeed of light.
Sorry, Officer.
Just explaining the theory of relativity. Twice.
Sheldon: For the record, he also thinks the Walgreens and the dry cleaners are out of this world.
Interesting hypothesis. Let’s apply the scientific method, perform an experiment.
It’s fascinating. Let me see if I can duplicate the result. Howard, I’ve always thought the lemon was an underrated fruit. Care to weigh in?
Oh, well.
What kind of tea would you like?
Two tea bags in one cup? You’re not at a rave.
I couldn’t agree more.

Oh, oh, on the contrary. Couples costumes are one of the few benefits of being in a relationship. Now imagine this, you and I entering Stuart’s party and all eyes turn to see America’s most beloved and glamorous couple.
R2-D2 and C-3PO. Dibs on Threepio.
Okay, I’m gonna let that slide because I know you’re hopped up on tea bags.
Fine. How about one of the most beguiling and influential couples of the 20th century? Hewlett and Packard. Dibs on Hewlett. What? You want to be Hewlett?
Night of the Living Garlic Bread?
I’m sorry, but these are just ordinary foods with the names bent into tortured puns. The dishes themselves are in no way Halloweenie.
What are you smiling at?
A Tardis makes no sense. It’s a time machine from a science-fiction show. It has nothing to do with Halloween. That being said, if you don’t get a Tardis, you stink and your party stinks.
Yes! This party just became a major rager.
Yes.
We seem to have different approaches here. I was going for helpful honesty. I have no idea what you’re doing.
Okay. If you think being nice will get him to shut up, I’ll try it.
Look at that, the problem solved itself.
What if we were to go as dinner table favourites salt and pepper?
No, I don’t think so. Those dolls represent three things I do not care for, clowns, children and raggediness. I think it’s a lost cause.
What’s a hickey?
I should’ve picked hickey.
It was a compromise. I lost.
Raj: Hey, Stuart, I see you’re getting ready for your Halloween party.
Would you like me to help? I do have a certain je ne sais quois when it comes to soirees.
You know, you don’t worry about money. I’ll take care of everything.
Yeah, you’ll love it. Ain’t no party like a Koothra-party.
Before I forget, I’d like your opinion on the menus I’ve prepared for the Halloween party. The theme is food that goes bump in the night.
It’s funny because bread sounds like dead.
Ooh, Hallow-weenies! That’s a good one. They’ll pair nicely with my Draculoni and Cheese. How do I do it?
So, I thought the photo booth for the party could either be creepy like a mummy’s tomb, or they also have the Tardis from Doctor Who.
Oh, by the way, can I borrow your bullwhip and fedora?
I was thinking of dressing up as Indiana Jones’ mocha-skinned love child. Indian Jones.
Oh, Howard, I’ve got a party to plan. Don’t make me pull it out of you.
Can you believe Stuart’s walking around taking credit for this party?
What do you mean who cares? Look at what I pulled off here. The DJ’s on fire, there’s a Tardis photo booth in the back room, and, oh, my God, the food. Stuart wanted Kraft Draculoni and cheese.
Is this about the space thing again?
Amy: Ladies night at the Cheesecake Factory. Does it get any better than this?
Question. Do you think your husband’s fondness for turtlenecks is an expression of longing for his missing foreskin?
That’s not always true. Last night I gave Sheldon my best come-hither look, and he responded by explaining how wheat came to be cultivated.
He takes hypotheses and designs protocols to determine their accuracy.
I think I’m gonna try green tea mixed with lemon zinger.
So, listen, Sheldon, I was thinking, since this is gonna be our first Halloween party as boyfriend and girlfriend, I thought it might be fun for us to go in a couples costume.
Really? I find that inconsistent with everything I know about you.
Sheldon, when I said couples costume, I meant like Romeo and Juliet or Cinderella and Prince Charming, not two robots from some silly movie I don’t even like.
I make compromises for you all the time. Just this once, can’t we find something that we’re both happy with?
You know salt makes me retain water and my cousin William was ground to death in a pepper factory accident. How about Raggedy Ann and Andy? I loved them growing up.
No. There are certain things that say to the world, I have a boyfriend, and he’s not made up. Matching costumes, hickeys and sex tapes. Pick one.
I’m Raggedy Ann, and he’s Raggedy C-3PO.
Penny: I hope so.
It’s not getting any better. (Text tone) Ugh. It’s Leonard. He wants to go costume shopping later.
I do, it’s just he wants to go to that party at the comic book store. A lot of the guys that hang out there are kind of creepy.
I’m, I’m sorry, Amy. You were saying something about Howard’s foreskin?
Yeah, I’m gonna go. It’s just not my idea of a good time.
Well, yeah, he’s my boyfriend. Isn’t that, like, his job?
Letting him make me happy.
I guess I could probably try a little harder.
Yeah, that’s kind of a problem.
Not really clear on what he does.
Yeah, I’m not really clear on what that means.
Yeah, you’re really just making it worse.
Anybody home?
I just thought I’d stop by and say hello.
No, I know. It’s long overdue. So, what ya doing? Better not be building a robot girlfriend.
You’re kidding.
Ooh! What’s going on in here?
What, is it secret?
Oh. You might want to put a sign on it.
Ah. Danger. Sure, sure. Yeah. What’s, what’s that?
Wow. High-techie-techie. What’s this little box?
Ooh, low-techie-techie. So, what are you working on right now?
Yeah?
Sharp. Thanks to the machine we saw earlier.
Wow. That is amazing.
What do you mean? (Leonard flicks a switch. The hologram changes to a view of the planet Earth). Oh! Wow!
Hmm.
Sometimes I forget how smart you are.
Take off your clothes.
Yeah. You got a problem with that?
Really? Never?
Whoa! That’s heavy.
No. Why?
Whoa! That is very cool.
Getting a little less cool, Leonard.
There we go.
Oh, my God, you guys look adorable.
No, sexy cop. Slutty cop only came with a skirt and two badges.
I thought we said in the car, no accents?
Bernadette: I thought you liked Halloween.
Like my husband?
Nice try, but you have to go to that party because we’re going.
Leonard does thing he doesn’t like to make you happy.
I just think in relationships you get back what you put into them.
You could start by taking an interest in his work.
He’s an experimental physicist.
Yeah, you mentioned it once or twice.
Okay, we need to talk.
Howie, I know you went to space. I’m incredibly proud of you. But you might want to try and not bring it up every minute.
Tonight at dinner you went on bout it for an hour straight.
I’m just saying, people are getting a little tired of it.
Of course you can. But maybe a good rule would be to wait for people to bring it up.
I love you.
How do I look?
Uh-oh, is someone a little blue? Come on, Howie, that’s like the funniest thing I’ve ever said in my life. What do you say? You ready to go?
What are you talking about? It’ll be fun. All your friends’ll be there.
No, if I’m there alone, people might think I’m just a really short person from Avatar.
Hey, I just spent the last three hours colouring myself blue. I’m gonna be washing paint out of my Smurf for a month.
Yeah, well, now you’re a Smurf. Keep walking.
Thanks, so do you. Slutty cop?
And Albert Einstein?
Whoa, Drinky Smurf. Can I talk to you for a second?
You, out! You are being very rude.
Me? What did I do?
I’m always on your side.
Just what?
Plain old Howard Wolowitz is the best guy I know.
No, I’m not. I married him. On purpose. Come here.
I love you, too.
Hey, what you watching?
Witch: The monster foods, they’re really fun.
Howard (in a squeaky voice): Oh, Howie, stop talking about space so much. Nobody likes it.
Penny (emerging from Tardis): Nothing to see here. Just sexy police business.
Buzz (on video, handing Halloween candy: Here you go. It’s a Milky Way. The Milky Way’s a galaxy in space. I’ve been in space. Here’s a Mars bar. I’m an astronaut. And this one’s a Moon Pie. I walked on the Moon. What have you done?
